qas.question: What have been constantly found in religious or ritual use?
What seeks to limit the use of polysyllabic characters?
What is sometimes written as a single character?

context: The use of such contractions is as old as <a0_0>Chinese characters<a0_0/> themselves, and they have frequently been found in religious or ritual use. In the Oracle Bone script, personal names, ritual items, and even phrases such as 受又(祐) shòu yòu "receive blessings" are commonly contracted into single characters. A dramatic example is that in medieval manuscripts 菩薩 púsà "<a2_0>bodhisattva<a2_0/>" (simplified: 菩萨) is sometimes written with a single character formed of a 2×2 grid of four 十 (derived from the grass radical over two 十). However, for the sake of consistency and standardization, the <a1_0>CPC<a1_0/> seeks to limit the use of such polysyllabic characters in public writing to ensure that every character only has one syllable.
